WRITING.TEXT: It's like you were reading my shower thoughts! #8203; I've often wondered if they knew they could get back, or if they had to take an educated guess.

WRITING.TITLE: Was the Mercedes AMG 'double stack' the smoothest pit stop of all-time?
WRITING.TEXT: Was the Mercedes AMG 'double stack' the smoothest pit stop of all-time? #8203; Maybe it's just because it was so recent, but with the pressure of having to make a faultless pit stop, the Mercedes AMG F1 team made it look so simple, and nobody broke stride. #8203; I know the Williams team have had some fast pit stops (maybe because the car is so slow to get to them?) but I'm struggling to think of a better stop in my 20-odd years of watching F1. https://preview.redd.it/megk42665zs21.jpg?width=1024 amp;format=pjpg amp;auto=webp amp;s=3296fc14b3ed951162e9019599ef0ac0371807f4
AH yes, that was a good one! Somehow I'd forgotten.
True, that one probably shades it for the addition of the quick thinking.
Haha, well I'm glad I asked, as I've been reminded of RBR from last year.
Wow, that's terrible! And so insensitive :-(
Well themlmbossbabe is now my new favourite account on IG haha!

If your SM handles match your business name, then I think it's probably overkill to have the social icons on the card. #8203; I prefer to have them on an email signature. #8203; The person has your card, so they can email you. Your reply will have direct links to social channels. #8203; Personally I think if you like the minimalist look, then go with that.
I think you've summed it up perfectly, and better than I did in my original question!
Ah yes, good point, they dealt a psychological blow with the move
Oh yes, that was amazing!
Haha, that's brilliant! #8203; Did it make you a RBR fan in the process?

Sure they may have been slower, but when compared to other double stacks that often look clunky (ie the second car ends up being stationary behind the first car and everyone panicking) this one \*looked\* like it was effortless.

There are several apps, but they're all (in my experience) unreliable as they were showing friends that had interacted with my content as inactive/ghost followers. #8203; So far, the best way I've found to do a clear out is to jump onto something like Upwork and hire someone for a few $ an hour to keep going through the list and unfollowing people. #8203; Give them some criteria like 'look for followers that have names that are random letters/numbers thrown together' and so on, then get them to block or unfollow those accounts first. #8203; That should refine the list a lot, then you can do a sweep once the number is more manageable. #8203; Keep in mind they'll only be able to unfollow about 100 people an hour, so with 11,000 it'll take some time. #8203; Then to get it turned around, initially, you're going to have to do some hard yards leaving genuine comments on accounts. I'd search for hashtags (or local area if it's a bricks amp; mortar place) and interact with people who look like they're doing some DIY, renovations, building etc.

Try eClincher, it's pretty stable. #8203; There was an issue that they had as well though, where if a 'location' was added, then the post failed. #8203; Maybe check with Loomly amp; BUffer to see if they had a problem too?

IMO I think you're opening line puts them off. #8203; Saying you're new \*implies\* that you're still figuring it all out (although you mentioned the business is new, you're not new to SMM, they don't know that) so I would lead with value. #8203; Let them know you've done some analysis and believe you can help them get 'x result' and would like to show them how you can do it, for free. #8203; List some bullet points that you would like to expand on during a call. #8203; Sure it will take longer, but it shows you care and have taken the time to learn about them, not just blasted emails to a cold list.
I love how Lewis always talks to his cars, he comes across as quite spiritual and 'connected' to everything around him.

A broad job title could be something like 'Strategy Consultant' but the bigger challenge than coming up with a name will be proving you can get a client results. #8203; And the results \*they\* want, not the results you think they should want. #8203; In the early days while you're starting out (sorry I'm assuming you're starting out) then a lot of clients would expect you to provide the content too, but if you're not good at this, then I'd suggest finding someone on Upwork who is. #8203; And, you can use it as an upsell. #8203; Consulting = x price. Consulting + content creation = y price
Ah yes, that's right, he looked very emotional. I can't remember the exact race a few years back, when he kept having a run of mechanicals, where he seemed to be pleading with the car to get better.
Definitely start with Canva. #8203; It's simple with 'drag and drop' and it's super easy to overlay text, and make borders etc. #8203; It's free, or to unlock more features you can pay a monthly fee.
Feels just as incredible now, over 30 years later. #8203; An artist behind the wheel.
Even if it has flaws (I'm no fact-checker) it's so visually appealing. #8203; Really looking forward to seeing the 'perfect' version at some point.
Nice one, they should definitely give you the job for the rest of the season.
Always like when a former pro gives heir opinion on things like this since they know what it takes to make it.
Hope this is true! Loved going to this race, somehow it was cheaper for me to fly to KL and buy a grandstand ticket than to get a similar ticket in Melbourne, where I lived...

Yeah, I think so too. #8203; Starting to wonder if all the tinkering people want to do is actually going to make it worse. #8203; Throughout the years there is always 1-2-3 teams who are more dominant, always going in cycles.

I think this is probably too high-level for what you're after, but maybe a start? #8203; [https://f1chronicle.com/getting-a-grip-on-f1-tyre-changes-for-2019/](https://f1chronicle.com/getting-a-grip-on-f1-tyre-changes-for-2019/) #8203; Sorry I don't know the exact answer myself to be more help.
Past would have to be Schumacher. #8203; Currently I think it would be Hamilton. He seems to leave no stone unturned and takes a holistic approach to making himself better both in and out of the car.
Might have to 'forget' to return that one!

Well you have a lot going on haha. #8203; Something to seriously consider is getting something like eClincher so you can create a weeks worth of posts at once then schedule them for posting, because it is a huge time suck to think of content every day, then try and post it on your phone, switching accounts etc. #8203; Just get into a zone, create everything, and schedule. For the amount of accounts you're looking at, I'd set aside a good 3-4 hours initially. #8203; When you do this, you can spend more time on arguably the most important part: engagement, Leaving genuine comments (and likes) on pics for people you think may want to follow you and become a customer. #8203; If I was starting this, I would go all-in first on your partner's account as it can be 'easier' to build a following for someone who is good looking than for a business/product. #8203; Get her alllllll the teeth whitening and skinny tea endorsements! #8203; Then once she has an audience, she can be the 'influencer' for the other things you want to launch. #8203; Consistency is key, again if it was me I'd outsource heavy lifting things like creating imagery, hashtag research, even the actual scheduling so you can focus on engaging captions and interacting with people.
New best supplier!!

Do loads of offsite SEO like link building, outreach, asking people to add infographic + link to their site etc. #8203; And if they complain about results, say it's cos you can only do 50% of the job required. #8203; Just set expectations well in advance! Be clear on what you can/can't do and what they can expect. #8203; Or... #8203; Find out if you can be connected with the people who \*can\* make the necessary website changes.

It can be a frustrating process, there are a lot of agencies out there who promise the world and deliver very little. #8203; It can be unusual/difficult to find one person who can do all of these things, and do them really well, so finding someone who can essentially 'project manage' a team of people and use their network may be a better fit. #8203; If you like, feel free to message me and we can chat more, as what my team and I do is we work on a revenue split, rather than charging you a flat fee. #8203; So if you make money, we make money, if you don't, we don't :-)

Haha yeah it gets confusing and can be expensive. I've used a bunch, like Buffer, Hootsuite, Sendible, and eClincher. I'm liking eClincher the most for functionality and reliability. You can do things tag accounts and add location in IG with it. eClincher also finds relevant hashtags for you. You put one in, let's say '#InstaModel' and it will find some that are similar. Personally I prefer to make my own 'bank' and save them in Evernote, then copy/paste them in. Using a ration of 10 hashtags between 5000-10000 posts, 5 hashtags from 10000 to 50000 posts, 10 hashtaggs from 50000 to 100000 posts, and 5 'free kicks' with posts in the millions, or room for branded/event specific hashtags. Takes about 20 minutes, but you can keep them for months and they'll be the most relevant. BTW if you do go with eClincher, would you mind helping me out? They pay a referral fee, you'd just need to send me the email address you register with if that's ok?

This might be an over-simplifaction without having all the context around the event, but I'd ask them :-) #8203; So I'm making an assumption that people have an idea of the sport/event, or something close to it, and even if the sport is newly invented, there is something it resembles. #8203; What I would do is then work out where the people who already follow the similar sport hang out, both online and offline, and ask them. #8203; For example if you're making a new NFL, then you know NFL fans hang out in bars watching games, and you can find places like subreddits and Facebook groups where they discuss it. #8203; Then, ask! #8203; People are often really happy to help when the person asking is honest about why they're asking. #8203; Then from the answers, you actually get specific wording you can use in content (landing pages, FB ads, YouTube scripts etc) as if one person in your niche is thinking/feeling something, it will most likely resonate with others who follow the same sport. #8203; It can be harder and more uncomfortable going out and asking, but I've always found it gets the best responses and information.
Their constant emails are annoying, but the guys at BlasterPro have a pretty simple tool with no watermark, and they render really fast so efficient to use as well.
The one on the right can't believe what is happening to the one on the left.
Loved the honesty in his interview after this, so refreshing to watch the interviews of the 'new generation' drivers as opposed to the pre-planned statements we often get.

I like how she just followed the script and forged on anyway. #8203; Her upline will love her, she doesn't even know when she's getting humiliated haha. #8203; Love how her way of enticing her 'friend' is just to tell her to educate herself, and say 'is not' for the pyramid scheme.

Best place to start then is the free 'Facebook Blueprint' training. #8203; It will quickly take you through the basics, then up to high-level stuff like running paid promotions. #8203; If this is going to be part of your job, then let your boss know you need a few days to work through as much of the training as possible, then you'll be good to go :-)
You're welcome :-)

If you can only send emails (I'm assuming this is your list and someone else is managing it?) then try case studies. #8203; Tell stories of real-life people and the results they got from attending your event. #8203; A story shows someone they can get the result they want too and adds credibility, and when sent consistently, are more effective than just blasting the list when you want to sell something.

WRITING.TITLE: Ayrton Senna: 25 Years On (Tributes)
WRITING.TEXT: Always such an emotional day for so many of us. #8203; Personally I've not done anything today other than watch YouTube clips and read tributes, so I thought I'd share a few articles here for anyone having a day of nostalgia. #8203; [https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2019/apr/29/ayrton-senna-25-years-f1-hero](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2019/apr/29/ayrton-senna-25-years-f1-hero) #8203; [https://f1chronicle.com/ayrton-senna-25-years-on/](https://f1chronicle.com/ayrton-senna-25-years-on/) #8203; [https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2014/apr/30/ayrton-senna-death-formula-one-20-years](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2014/apr/30/ayrton-senna-death-formula-one-20-years) https://preview.redd.it/06tx6jebghv21.jpg?width=1002 amp;format=pjpg amp;auto=webp amp;s=dac0cd2babc5cd0bee203190b20d7c6aa066e07a

Start with yourself. #8203; Build your personal brand using the techniques you have been learning by applying them to your own social media accounts. #8203; Then you will have proof that you can do what you say you can do, and you will also get the real life learning experiences. #8203; Personally I think building your own brand is more beneficial than volunteering to build a company profile for someone, as they'll essentially just be in it for the free work, and after a little while you'll resent doing it for free, whereas when you build your own profile you're still getting a positive ROI.

Yep, just you. #8203; He's speaking more to the 'masses' than people working in marketing, trying to inspire them to think differently. #8203; Also keep in mind not everyone started the 'journey' together on Day 1 x number of years ago. #8203; Every day there are people finishing school, leaving jobs, and so on who haven't heard the message because it wasn't relevant to them 1-2-3 years ago, but is now :-)

Wow, thank you for this, I totally thought it was the 'you need this!' variety. #8203; So on one hand I feel like a dumbass, but on the other, if a hun ever tells me to do my research I'm safe in the knowledge that I have now educated myself. #8203; Though why do I have a funny feeling the huns think it is the 'you need this!' variety??

WRITING.TITLE: 2019 Monaco Grand Prix Driver Tyre Choices
WRITING.TEXT: The FIA communicated to Pirelli each team #8217;s tyre choices for the forthcoming Monaco Grand Prix (May 23-26). #8203; I'm curious to know why some drivers have selected two sets of the C3 hard compound tyre for a circuit like Monaco, any ideas? https://preview.redd.it/vu1u21qtk9y21.jpg?width=1200 amp;format=pjpg amp;auto=webp amp;s=67b8d6e9e2e8549fcaa75ad75d8e085f08675585
Ah yes, good point!
True. Sometimes I'm not sure if I'm more confused or less confused with the new naming convention.

Case studies. #8203; People like stories, so share stories of the time Bob had to get X Document across the other side of town in 13 minutes, called you guys up, you delivered in 11, and helped Bob to achieve whatever his goal was. #8203; If you can, make it humorous. Even though it's a real story, it's still a bit of an ad, because you're not going to do a case study on the time the courier dropped the package down a flight of stairs and smashed everything inside ;-)

Yes, it's so much simpler during the race, you can either see the tyre from the footage, and/or have a quick glance at the chart on the left of the TV to see who is running what, I like that aspect of it.

We have a news-based site rather than product or service, but we're struggling for traffic (so not much revenue from Adsense) so would appreciate any and all feedback. #8203; [https://f1chronicle.com/](https://f1chronicle.com/)

We use 'Newspaper' from TagDiv ( [https://tagdiv.com/](https://tagdiv.com/) ) on our Formula 1 website: #8203; [https://f1chronicle.com/](https://f1chronicle.com/) #8203; You get a fair few customisable options, and it connects easily with Adsense too. #8203; And if you don't like the black background, you can have white.
You're welcome :-)

Try 'Tribe' as they're excellent at connecting you with influencers as they can help you to craft your message. #8203; [https://www.tribegroup.co/](https://www.tribegroup.co/) #8203; The infuencers then see what you're doing, submit a quote, and you can accept/decline or message them. #8203; Saves a lot of legwork looking for and messaging random accounts!

Video, video, video. #8203; You're going to need to cut together highlights from the previous event so it looks appealing to people, making them feel like they're going to miss out if they don't go. #8203; Play on people's fear of missing out. #8203; Also video's from people who went last year, talking about how amazing it was and how they can't wait to go again. Doesn;t need to be world class, just shot on a phone will do. #8203; Then you could potentially even try IG 'influencers'. If you don't have a buget it'll be tough, but hey, maybe you could set up like a 'VIP Room' at the event that has catering etc and give the influencers a ticket for them and two friends. Then you'll get the double-whammy of them promoting the event before it happens, and creating content while they're at the event. #8203; Just be prepared for a lot of rejection, as most influencers like to be paid in money not free things :-)
This is awesome, well done, such a great tribute.

WRITING.TITLE: Is Formula 1 Boring? - Article with analysis
WRITING.TEXT: I know I'm putting myself in the line of fire here, but after every race it seems to have become popular to jump onto FB pages etc and complain that F1 is boring and has to change. #8203; I'm old enough to remember other periods of domination like the one we're seeing with Mercedes now, so I took a week or so to analyse previous periods (such as the years Ferrari/Schumacher dominated) and compared winning percentages across years as it seemed the most accurate way to compare, given the number of races per season and the points on offer have changed over the years. #8203; I'd be keen to hear feedback on any areas I might have missed, and if I should do something similar to compare backmarkers? Williams are slow and off the pace, but how do they compare to previous backmarkers? Any interest? #8203; [https://f1chronicle.com/is-formula-1-boring/](https://f1chronicle.com/is-formula-1-boring/) https://preview.redd.it/5ayi2287enz21.jpg?width=1024 amp;format=pjpg amp;auto=webp amp;s=bbe57ae49372999c20302e8496e8226035613f37

Haha, my grandma said the same thing! #8203; Great point, the powers that be would pay much more attention to viewer numbers than they would people complaining on social media. #8203; I suspect the people who complain don't switch off because they still love the sport, but they also love getting the comments/likes after they post ;-)
Agreed, I personally don't think it needs reform. #8203; The other teams need to grasp the opportunity of striving to be as good as Merc.
Excellent point. #8203; It would be so interesting to get some stats on who follows a team/driver vs who follows the sport in general.

Great observation, and I think you're exactly right. #8203; Not having that 'back story' is the big reason I couldn't get into NASCAR. It seemed you could just turn it on, watch the car fly around a bit, and that was that. #8203; That, or maybe I had unrealistic expectations after Days of Thunder!

Yeah I was in two minds about looking at season by season, or 'dominant period' as a whole. #8203; In the end I went for season by season because of the human nature aspect of 'that season was the best!' and 'the last season was so boring' etc etc... #8203; Thanks for sharing the other analysis too, I'll update the article and link to it this afternoon.

I agree with all your points, especially the one about RBR/Honda, they're starting to look really strong together. #8203; The only thing I'd disagree with is the predictability part, I remember in 2002 and 2004 not always staying up late to watch the races, having the feeling Schumacher would win in a canter, then waking up and seeing that's what happened ;-)

True, JPM certainly did make things more interesting! Perhaps being a disgruntled McLaren fan I was watching through frustration ;-) I suspect you're right, RBR have some excellent minds at work, and have a good budget too. Likewise Honda have some great minds, it won't surprise me at all if they knock off Mercedes sooner rather than later.
Haha, could be worse I guess, could be Williams fans ;-)

WRITING.TITLE: 2019 Monaco GP Day 1 Performance Graphic
WRITING.TEXT: An interesting graphic that shows where Mercedes rivals were losing time throughout the Thursday practice sessions. #8203; There's a lot of pain in the slow corners for Williams! https://preview.redd.it/zjmjnydzv1031.png?width=982 amp;format=png amp;auto=webp amp;s=b25529d860c29d697e5a4c75a54566cdca1e202a
Yeah if Max can find a little more straight line speed, and Haas can take those slow corners a little quicker, they will definitely push the Ferrari's! Would be an amazing result for Haas.
Straight from F1 direct. I'm on one of their media distribution lists, and they sent it out this morning. If they keep sending them over the race weekend, I'll keep sharing them.
Sadly just the charts. The data that makes them would be awesome though!
No sorry, I meant from the media officer at Formula 1, he sent it out directly.

It sucks that this is happening, but from experience, the absolute best thing you can do is enrol him in some personal development courses that help develop self confidence and skills he can use after school, such as public speaking. #8203; And not an online course, that won't help, an in-person one where he has to go and talk with real people. #8203; Now given his age, and the fact he will most likely resist your efforts, I'd also suggest you go with him to the first one or two. Hey, you'll pick up a few things as well :-) #8203; Then, as his confidence develops, his self-esteem will approve, and he will end up becoming a leader. #8203; The teachers can't do much to help, but being empowered and confident is a skill that will serve him well and put him ahead of the majority of other kids his age.

If you have a little bit of budget and the time to do it yourself, then I would highly recommend doing the Authority Hacker training, then follow their techniques, and you will rank. #8203; I've used their strategies for three websites now, all going great guns.

What should you do? #8203; Walk away... #8203; But if you're going to do it, how much work is involved for you? #8203; $500 kinda seems like a made up amount, and works out to $1 per keyword which is insane. #8203; For that many keywords, I'd offer something like a monthly retainer + a % revenue split. #8203; You could get all the words there, but then what? How are they going to stay there? So, monthly work, and a share of the income. Win-win for both of you.
eClincher. #8203; Simple to use, their reports are excellent (you can brand them too) and now they have 'first comment' functionality so you can put hashtags in the comment straight away.

Not that I can think of. #8203; It's pretty good at replicating IG, because you can also tag a location, tag an account (you have to know the exact username, it's not pre-emptive) and you can look for relevant hashtags if you don't already have a bank of hashtags saved up. #8203; Does everything I need and it's reliable, unlike previous platforms I've used such as Sendible and Hootsuite.

Sendible in particular always had problems with posts failing and reports not working. #8203; And their customer service sucked. It was never their fault, according to them, always blaming everyone else including us as the users. #8203; For me the extra $ is worth spending to know the posts will go as scheduled, or the support team will help rectify things.

WRITING.TITLE: 2019 Canadian Grand Prix: Selected Tyre Sets Per Driver
WRITING.TEXT: Such varied choices for Canada, interesting to see McLaren and Racing Point only taking two sets of Medium's. https://preview.redd.it/7g9opzck51131.jpg?width=4546 amp;format=pjpg amp;auto=webp amp;s=0d724ff76b8722c0c68c70ad240343a062b8bdc4

Nope, these are people using bots to automatically comment on posts based on hashtags. #8203; By 'colaborate' they will want you to pay them money to get a post featured on their account, or they might give you a discount code if they sell products. #8203; Just report the comment as spam, block the account, and move on :-)
Re your second point, I love trying to work out the strategies when I see these graphs too! Has me wondering how much the experts on each team can read into it. A fair amount I would imagine.

Yeah, the Williams selection was boggling! Like you, I've paid them no attention at all. I'm wondering if they have some strategy like 'we'll change to the hards early on, then with a huge slice of luck one day there could be a safety car at the exact right moment and we'll vault towards the front' Seems a long shot though...
This wins the internet today!

Toggl is the best one I've seen. #8203; Easy to give each task you're working on a name, and easy to choose which client it goes towards. #8203; Then you can download various reports, either by time, or with detail of what you've done.
Haha, I was thinking the exact same thing as I read the post!

From experience the two best things you can do to help are: #8203; 1) When you get home from work, you look after the baby so your wife can do whatever she wants. Sorry f this means giving a few after work activities/things for relaxation up haha! But the baby will be asleep pretty early anyway. For the first couple of weeks you'll think 'omg I'll never get to do anything other than clean and wash again!' but then you get better/faster at it, and things calm down. #8203; 2) If you can afford it, keep the nanny around for one day a week so your wife can do other things. The other things might still be baby related, but having that time means she gets to keep her 'identity' rather than have it wrapped up in the baby. Not sure if I explained that well, but point being, she will love having one day a week where she can do her own things.
You're welcome, happy to help :-)
